intro: Seriphidium tridentatum subsp. parishii, commonly known as the Parish's tansy, is a member of the Asteraceae family and is native to arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in desert or semi-desert environments. The plant features yellow composite flowers arranged in flat-topped clusters, which are characteristic of the daisy family. Its leaves are usually finely divided and covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, aiding in water conservation. It is adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and low precipitation, making it a resilient species in harsh climates.
